Total Ca and total P were measured by wet chemistry (Agricultural Experiment Station Chemical Laboratories, the University of Missouri, Columbia, MO). The 25OHD concentrations were measured via LC-MS/MS method (Heartland Assays, Ames, IA). avP, available phosphorus. The birds and feed in each cage were weighed on d 7, 14, 20, and 26 to determine BWG and FI. Feed conversion ratio was calculated from BWG and FI. Mortality was documented collectively for corrected FCR calculation. At 5 DPI (d 19), one bird each pen was humanely euthanized via cervical dislocation for blood collection. At 6 DPI (d 20), 7 more birds per cage were sacrificed for sample collection. Intestinal permeability was determined by using fluorescein isothiocyanate–dextran ( On 6 DPI (d 20), 3 chickens per cage were euthanized for the assessment of duodenal, jejunal-ileal, and cecal lesions.  Fresh fecal samples were collected from 6 to 8 DPI and stored at 4°C for further processing. For analysis, approximately 5 g of feces was weighed and thoroughly vortexed with 40 mL of distilled water. Then, 1 mL of the mixed sample was diluted with 9 mL of saturated salt water and vortexed again. Subsequently, the number of oocysts was counted using a McMaster chamber (Vetlab Supply, Palmetto Bay, FL). The methodology for oocyst counting was outlined by  On 6 DPI (d 20), samples for intestinal morphology analysis were collected from the middle part of the duodenal loop (duodenum), 10 cm above the Meckel's diverticulum (jejunum), and 10 cm below the Meckel's diverticulum (ileum). The digesta was flushed out using 1 × phosphate-buffered saline ( The samples were homogenized using a bead beater (Biospec Products, Bartlesville, OK) in QiAzol lysis reagent (Qiagen Inc., Valencia, CA), and total RNA was extracted according to the manufacturer's instructions. The purity and quantity of RNA were assessed with a Nanodrop 2000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA). The RNA concentration was standardized, and reverse transcription was performed using a high-capacity cDNA synthesis kit (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA). Quantitative PCR was conducted in duplicate with SYBR Green Master mix (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) using a Step One thermocycler (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) under the following conditions for all genes: 95°C denaturation for 10 min, followed by 40 cycles at 95°C for 15 s, annealing at the appropriate temperature for 20 s, and extension at 72°C for 15 s, according to our previous study ( List of primers for qPCR. The control and prevention of coccidiosis has relied on anticoccidial drugs and coccidial vaccinations. With the growing consumer demand for poultry products raised without antibiotics (NAE or ABF), the industry has been forced to rely more heavily on coccidiosis vaccination programs ( In the current study, reducing Ca and avP in the diets did not show any significant differences in growth performance before  Reducing Ca and avP in the diet ( Regarding daily FI, an interaction effect between the coccidial vaccine and diets was observed on 7 DPI in the current study. In unvaccinated groups, the NC and NC+25OHD groups had higher FI than the PC group, while in vaccinated groups, the NC and NC+PHY+25OHD diets resulted in lower FI compared to the PC group. This suggests that the vaccine may have influenced the birds' feeding behavior in response to dietary Ca and avP levels. The coccidial vaccine increased FI on 6 DPI but decreased it on 10 DPI, indicating that the vaccine provided immunological protection by stimulating FI during the peak infection but later suppressed it during the recovery phase. Dietary treatments also significantly influenced daily FI. On 9 DPI, the NC diet decreased FI compared to the PC diet, but supplementing phytase or 25OHD, or both, improved FI to a similar level as the PC birds. This result highlights the importance of maintaining adequate dietary Ca and avP levels, or providing supplemental phytase or vitamin D Our current results showed that coccidial vaccine significantly decreased FITC-d levels, suggesting the coccidial vaccine effectively reduced  While we did not observe any difference in intestinal lesion scores between unvaccinated and vaccinated birds in this study, the relationship between lesion scores and the clinical impact of coccidiosis is nuanced ( The differential effect of the coccidial vaccine on oocyst shedding of different  The NC+PHY+25OHD group exhibited an increase in  In addition to improving BW and BWG in broilers post-infection, results from the current study showed that coccidial vaccination also supported the growth of the small intestine during this period. The notable increase in villus height in the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum, along with the increased VH:CD ratio in the duodenum of vaccinated birds at 6 DPI (d 20), suggests that the coccidial vaccine promotes intestinal health and nutrient absorption by maintaining or enhancing the structure of the intestinal mucosa ( Tight junction proteins play a crucial role in maintaining intestinal barrier integrity in chickens, particularly when birds are under disease conditions. These proteins form the paracellular barrier that regulates the selective permeability of the intestinal epithelium ( In summary, the current study investigated the effects of coccidial vaccination and dietary interventions on growth performance, intestinal health, and tight junction protein expression in broiler chickens challenged with  The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

title: Application of the world guidelines for falls prevention and management’s risk stratification algorithm to patients on a frailty intervention pathway and the potential utility of sensory impairment information
abstract: The 2022 world guidelines for falls prevention and management suggest measuring sensory function including dizziness, vision, and hearing. These variables are not included in the falls risk stratification algorithm. This study sought to investigate the utility of the guidelines and potential avenues for improvement. This study applied the falls risk stratification recommendations and reviewed the individual sensory impairment risk factor variables predictive of falls and falls risk grouping in those assessed by a frailty intervention team (FIT) based in an emergency department (ED). Patients over 65 years old who attended the ED and had a comprehensive geriatric assessment carried out by FIT over a period of four months were included in this retrospective cross-sectional study. Patient characteristics, medication, physical and sensory function status data was retrieved and analysed with respect to falls and falls risk grouping. Data was gathered retrospectively from 392 patients. Excluding those with missing data, almost all attendees were in the high-risk of falls category ( Most older adults included in the analysis fell into the low- or high-risk categories, with a minority in the intermediate-risk category. This suggests that the inclusion criteria for the intermediate category could be altered for greater sensitivity. While impaired balance and vision were the most common impairments, hearing status, balance and dizziness were associated with risk group. These results, through a practical application of the world guidelines for falls to an acute clinical sample, raise the possibility of refining the falls risk stratification criteria, and highlight the capacity for additional sensory intervention to mitigate falls risk. The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12877-024-05405-3.
full_text:
A fall is defined as ‘ In the United Kingdom it is estimated that 30% of people aged 65 years or older, will fall at least once a year; and this increases to 50% for those aged over 80 years [ The recently published world guidelines for falls prevention and management [ The Irish Longitudinal Study on Ageing (TILDA) have recently implemented the framework in an observational study aiming to successfully differentiate those at greater risk of falling [ A Frailty Intervention Team (FIT) was established in October 2020, in the emergency department, at a large level 4 teaching hospital in Dublin’s north inner city. The FIT is an interdisciplinary group consisting of physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech and language therapy, dietetics, medical social work, pharmacy, nursing, therapy assistants, and medical team members. They complete comprehensive geriatric assessments (CGAs) for older adults, aged 65 years or older, that attend the emergency department. CGAs are completed by all members of the FIT at any stage and/or throughout their attendance at the emergency department. CGAs are utilised as a multidisciplinary diagnostic process to help the FIT identify the medical, psychosocial, and functional needs of older adults. There is strong evidence that in the medical setting, CGAs can guide the development of a coordinated plan to manage the health complexity, and to maximise overall health in older persons [ There is evidence highlighting that sensory issues are linked to an increased risk of falls. Particularly in older adults, hearing loss [ The primary aim of this study was to assess the utility of applying the world guidelines for falls prevention and management stratification algorithm [ The study was a retrospective cross-sectional assessment of patient data over a defined period of time. The primary research questions were: 
 Can the world guidelines for falls prevention and management stratification algorithm be successfully utilised in an emergency department setting? Are sensory variables related to falls and falls risk stratification? What other variables gathered by a CGA could inform the assessment of, and interventions for, falls risk? The authors used a form of convenience sampling. It was decided that a minimum of 200 patients would be needed to give a meaningful insight into the utility of falls guidelines stratification in this observational study. Following an assessment of a random two-week time window of the number of patients who had a CGA carried out, it was established that three months’ worth of data would be adequate accounting for patterns of missing data. Therefore, all patients aged 65 years or older, who attended the emergency department at the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital and who had a CGA carried out by the FIT between January 3rd and April 20th 2023 were included in the study. Patients younger than 65 years old, and those who attended the emergency department in the specified study period, but did not have a CGA completed by the FIT were excluded. Records were gathered by three of the authors (COC, SM, RK), who are clinicians authorised by the clinical audit and effectiveness committee to access and handle data. In cases where the patient was unable to provide information about their health (e.g., in cases of cognitive impairment), information was gathered from family members and/or carers, as appropriate, or from existing medical records (e.g., previous hearing test results saved on the patient management system). All participant records were pseudonymised before analysis. Sensory function status data was retrieved from a detailed CGA form completed for patients seen. Fall-risk-increasing drugs (FRIDs), as defined by Screening Tool of Older Persons Prescriptions in older adults with high fall risk (STOPPFall) [ The study protocol was reviewed and approved by the clinical audit and effectiveness committee, Quality and Patient Safety Directorate, at the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital, Dublin (Reference number: CA23-011, approved 22/02/2023). The world guidelines for falls prevention and management [ 
 World guideline for falls prevention and management algorithm for risk stratification, assessments and management / interventions for community-dwelling older adults [ The raw data was coded for analysis in the following way: Gender (female = 1, male = 2), History of falls in last 12 months (no = 0, yes = 1), Clinical frailty score [ In total, data was gathered retrospectively from 392 patients, 227 (57.8%) female, and 166 male. The mean age was 82 years old, with a range of 65 to 103 years. In total 134 (34.2%) patients presented at the emergency department with a fall, 255 (65.1%) presented for another reason and three records had missing data for presentation. Over half ( 
 Patient demographics Of those who presented, the majority ( 
 Waffle plot of risk stratification based on world guidelines for falls prevention and management. Low risk falls = less than one fall in past year; Low risk frailty = one fall in past year but no frailty or balance issues; High risk falls = greater than or equal to two falls in the past year; High risk frailty = one fall in the past year and frailty; Intermediate risk = one fall in the past year, balance issue and no frailty; N/A = not able to stratify patient because of missing data The relationships between the sensory variables vision loss, hearing loss, dizziness and balance issues and falls incidence in the past year were individually calculated, controlling for the influence of age, sex, and frailty. Hearing loss was a significant predictor of falls incidence, b = 0.68, z = 2.4,  In the low-risk group, the most common sensory issue was vision loss ( 
 Existence of sensory issues in each of the three risk groups following stratification. Odds ratios (OR) are the odds of being in the high-risk group compared to the low-risk group based on having versus not having the sensory issue. The odds ratio for each sensory issue in turn accounts for the effect of age, sex and frailty but not the effect of other sensory issues The CGA gathered information on interventions for hearing loss (hearing aids), vision loss (glasses) and balance issues (mobility aids). The results show that a majority of patients in the high-risk falls group with these sensory issues have already been given interventions. Discounting those for whom there is missing intervention data, in the high-risk falls group 74% of those with hearing loss had a hearing aid, 48% of those with vision loss had glasses and 70% of those with balance issues had mobility aids. There was a large amount of missing data for vision loss in particular (69%). There was missing intervention data of 37% and 1% for hearing and balance respectively. The figures mean there is some limited scope for dealing with untreated sensory problems. (Fig.  
 Number of high-risk patients experiencing vision loss, hearing loss and balance issues who are aided and not aided for the condition Pre-admission medicines reconciliations data was available for 94 participtants in our cohort. In the low-risk group ( The study results showed that the world guidelines for falls prevention and management’s risk stratification algorithm can be successfully utilised in a clinical population, sensory variables hearing loss and dizziness were significantly associated with falls incidence and hearing loss, balance and dizziness were significantly associated with risk grouping. In keeping with the findings of Hartley et al. (2023), who applied the stratification to a non-clinical population [ The study population consisted of older adults who were taken through a frailty screening. Frailty has been connected to the sensory variables of hearing loss [ Sensory interventions, such as hearing aids, have been shown to be related to a reduction in falls amongst older adults [ This study analysed data from 392 patients, however many patients’ CGAs were missing data for one or more variables. This meant that analysis controlling for the effects of other target variables was not possible given the increasingly small numbers of patients with complete data. Future research should analyse larger numbers of patients to assess the comparative impact of the target sensory variable given the presence or non-presence of other sensory impairments. This is also the case for other influential variables such as falls risk inducing medication and polypharmacy. Polypharmacy in particular is linked to a 21% increase in the rate of falls over a two-year period [ The world guidelines for falls prevention and management’s risk stratification algorithm can be utilised clinically, even in a sample of patients on a frailty intervention pathway which was designed before publication of the guidelines. Using the risk stratification algorithm, most of the included patients fell into either the high- or low-risk groups as has been shown in non-clinical populations. Only 4.8% of those stratified were categorised as intermediate risk. This may be accounted for due to the relatively frail nature of the cohort included but is similar to results from a non-clinical sample. Those with hearing impairment, balance issues, and dizziness, independent of frailty, age, and gender, were more likely to be categorised as high risk. This demonstrates the influence of sensory loss in falls risk, highlighting the potential importance of sensory assessment as part of a multi-factorial fall prevention strategy in older adults. Such improvements which utilise sensory impairment information could lead to earlier intervention and better health outcomes. Below is the link to the electronic supplementary material.
